TopicTitle: What Parts and Addons do you want to see made?

Articles.Content:
Greetings everyone!

I made a thread a few weeks ago called Greebles and Doodads, and from the responses I got it seems like there are big areas in the add-on supply that are left untouched.

Some ideas for part packs require programming, something I'm not too good with, so if there is anyone out there who would like to collaborate with me on something, then that would be awesome too.

Now I have a few weeks/months to kill while i look for a job, so I'm looking for things to practice my 3d Art on and i would love it if i could benefit people with these pieces.

So please folks, I would love suggestions for items and such!

Ideas list

  • Role Play parts
  • General Structural Pieces
  • Lights, glowing items and similar pieces
  • ship "Bulking" parts
  • Second Hand parts (Rusted and falling apart?)
  • Strange, Almost alien parts
  • Car Parts
  • Dropship parts
  • Army parts, not weapons exactly, but things that look milatary
  • Things like massive Soda for Bottle rockets
  • Podracer parts

Note that these parts will be custom items, As i do not like building other peoples creations (I mean like building Anakins podracer, instead i will build parts that look like they fit a podracer)

These parts will also follow the same general theme as stock parts.

If this thread is breaking any sub-forum rules then please notify me (I couldn't find anything saying i could not post this here)

Oh - another part that would be cool: a folding strut. What I specifically have in mind is something that is radial mounted, so that the strut is flush against the hull (like the landing gear). When activated, it would rotate out so it's perpendicular to the hull, and it would telescope to double length. It would be sized like the small struts, and it would have a small node on the end to attach parts. This would allow a satellite or whatever to be fairly compact at launch, and then it could extend antennas or sensors or whatever away from the probe body once it reaches orbit.
